title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Michael scored 260 points during his junior year on the school basketball team. He scored 20% more points during his senior year. How many points did he score during both years?

During his senior year Michael scored 260 * 20/100 = <<260*20/100=52>>52 points more.
So during his senior year Michael scored 260 + 52 = <<260+52=312>>312 points.
That means Michael scored during both years 312 + 260 = <<312+260=572>>572 points. Answer: \boxed{572}.


Question: Michael scored 260 points during his junior year on the school basketball team. He scored 20% more points during his senior year. How many points did he score during both years?

During his senior year, Michael scored 260 * 20/100 = <<260*20/100=52>>52 more points.
So, he scored 260 + 52 = <<260+52=312>>312 points during his senior year.
Therefore, Michael scored 260 + 312 = <<260+312=572>>572 points during both years. Answer: \boxed{572}.


Question: Michael scored 260 points during his junior year on the school basketball team. He scored 20% more points during his senior year. How many points did he score during both years?

During his senior year, Michael scored an additional 260 x 20/100 = <<260*20/100=52>>52 points.
So, he scored 260 + 52 = <<260+52=312>>312 points during his senior year.
Therefore, he scored a total of 260 + 312 = <<260+312=572>>572 points during both years. Answer: \boxed{572}.


Question: Michael scored 260 points during his junior year on the school basketball team. He scored 20% more points during his senior year. How many points did he score during both years?

During his senior year, Michael scored 260 x 20/100 = <<260*20/100=52>>52 points more than his junior year.
So, he scored a total of 260 + 52 = <<260+52=312>>312 points during his senior year.
Therefore, Michael scored a total of 260 + 312 = <<260+312=572>>572 points during both years. Answer: \boxed{572}.


Question: Michael scored 260 points during his junior year on the school basketball team. He scored 20% more points during his senior year. How many points did he score during both years?

Michael scored 260 points * .2 = <<260*.2=52>>52 more points his senior year.
That means Michael scored 260 points + 52 points = <<260+52=312>>312 points during his senior year.
Thus, Michael scored 260 points + 312 points = <<260+312=572>>572 points during both years. Answer: \boxed{572}.


Question: Michael scored 260 points during his junior year on the school basketball team. He scored 20% more points during his senior year. How many points did he score during both years?
text:
During his senior year, Michael scored an additional 20% of 260 points, which is equivalent to 260 * (20/100) = <<260*(20/100)=52>>52 points.
Therefore, during his senior year, Michael scored a total of 260 + 52 = <<260+52=312>>312 points.
Therefore, Michael scored a total of 260 + 312 = <<260+312=572>>572 points during both years. Answer: \boxed{572}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: James has 18 chocolate bars to sell for the swim team. He sold 5 last week and 7 this week. How many more chocolate bars does he need to sell?

James has sold a total of 5 + 7 = <<5+7=12>>12 chocolate bars.
Therefore, he still needs to sell 18 - 12 = <<18-12=6>>6 chocolate bars. Answer: \boxed{6}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Quinten sees three buildings downtown and decides to estimate their heights. He knows from a book on local buildings that the one in the middle is 100 feet tall. The one on the left looks like it is 80% of the height of the middle one. The one on the right looks 20 feet shorter than if the building on the left and middle were stacked on top of each other. How tall does Quinten estimate their total height to be?

The building on the left is 100 x 80% = <<100*80*.01=80>>80 feet tall.
The building on the right is 80 + 100 - 20 = <<80+100-20=160>>160 feet tall.
So, their total height is 100 + 80 + 160 = <<100+80+160=340>>340 feet. Answer: \boxed{340}.


Question: Quinten sees three buildings downtown and decides to estimate their heights. He knows from a book on local buildings that the one in the middle is 100 feet tall. The one on the left looks like it is 80% of the height of the middle one. The one on the right looks 20 feet shorter than if the building on the left and middle were stacked on top of each other. How tall does Quinten estimate their total height to be?

The building on the left is 80/100 * 100 feet = <<80/100*100=80>>80 feet tall.
The building on the right is 80 feet + 100 feet - 20 feet = <<80+100-20=160>>160 feet tall.
So in total, Quinten estimates the buildings are 100 feet + 80 feet + 160 feet = <<100+80+160=340>>340 feet tall. Answer: \boxed{340}.


Question: Quinten sees three buildings downtown and decides to estimate their heights. He knows from a book on local buildings that the one in the middle is 100 feet tall. The one on the left looks like it is 80% of the height of the middle one. The one on the right looks 20 feet shorter than if the building on the left and middle were stacked on top of each other. How tall does Quinten estimate their total height to be?

The building on the left is estimated to be 100 * .8 = <<100*.8=80>>80 feet tall.
The total height of both the left and middle buildings stacked on top of each other should be 100 + 80 = <<100+80=180>>180 feet.
So the building on the right is estimated to be 180 - 20 = <<180-20=160>>160 feet tall.
Therefore, Quinten estimates the total height of all three buildings to be 100 + 80 + 160 = <<100+80+160=340>>340 feet. Answer: \boxed{340}.


Question: Quinten sees three buildings downtown and decides to estimate their heights. He knows from a book on local buildings that the one in the middle is 100 feet tall. The one on the left looks like it is 80% of the height of the middle one. The one on the right looks 20 feet shorter than if the building on the left and middle were stacked on top of each other. How tall does Quinten estimate their total height to be?

The building on the left is estimated to be 0.8 * 100 = <<0.8*100=80>>80 feet tall.
The height of the left and middle buildings stacked on top of each other is 100 + 80 = <<100+80=180>>180 feet.
Thus, Quinten estimates the building on the right to be 180 - 20 = <<180-20=160>>160 feet tall.
Therefore, Quinten estimates the total height of the three buildings to be 100 + 80 + 160 = <<100+80+160=340>>340 feet. Answer: \boxed{340}.


Question: Derek is watching the construction cranes downtown and is trying to figure out how much taller they have to be than the building they are building. He sees one crane that is 228 feet tall finishing a building that was 200 feet tall. He sees another that is 120 feet tall finishing a building that is 100 feet tall. The final crane he sees is 147 feet tall, finishing a building that is 140 feet tall. On average, what percentage taller are the cranes than the building?

First find the height difference between the first crane and the building: 228 feet - 200 feet = <<228-200=28>>28 feet
Then divide that number by the height of the building and multiply by 100% to express the answer as a percentage: 28 feet / 200 feet * 100% = 14%
Then find the height difference between the second crane and the building: 120 feet - 100 feet = <<120-100=20>>20 feet
Then divide that number by the height of the building and multiply by 100% to express the answer as a percentage: 20 feet / 100 feet * 100% = 20%
Then find the height difference between the third crane and the building: 147 feet - 140 feet = <<147-140=7>>7 feet
Then divide that number by the height of the building and multiply by 100% to express the answer as a percentage: 7 feet / 140 feet * 100% = 5%
Finally, add the three height differences to find the total height difference: 14% + 20% + 5% = <<14+20+5=39>>39%
Finally, divide the total height difference by the number of cranes to find the average height difference: 39% / 3 cranes = <<39/3=13>>13%. Answer: \boxed{13}.


Question: Quinten sees three buildings downtown and decides to estimate their heights. He knows from a book on local buildings that the one in the middle is 100 feet tall. The one on the left looks like it is 80% of the height of the middle one. The one on the right looks 20 feet shorter than if the building on the left and middle were stacked on top of each other. How tall does Quinten estimate their total height to be?
text:
The building on the left is estimated to be 0.8 * 100 = <<0.8*100=80>>80 feet tall. 
The height of the left and middle buildings stacked on top of each other is 100 + 80 = <<100+80=180>>180 feet.
Thus, Quinten estimates the building on the right to be 180 - 20 = <<180-20=160>>160 feet tall. 
Therefore, Quinten estimates the total height of the three buildings to be 100 + 80 + 160 = <<100+80+160=340>>340 feet. Answer: \boxed{340}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: There are 20 cars lined up at a race. Each of the cars have 2 passengers and a driver, then when the cars go past the race’s halfway point, each car gains another passenger. The cars then continue racing, and the race finishes once every single car has passed the finish line. People who get into the cars have to stay inside of them until the race is finished. How many people are in the cars by the end of the race?

There are 20 cars in the race, each with a driver and 2 passengers initially. So, there are 1 + 2 = <<1+2=3>>3 people in each car.
Once the cars go past the halfway point, which is halfway through the race, they gain another passenger. Hence, there are now 2 + 1 = <<2+1=3>>3 passengers in each car.
So, at the end of the race, there are 3 passengers plus 1 driver in each car.
Therefore, the total number of people in the cars by the end of the race is 20 cars x 4 people per car = <<20*4=80>>80 people. Answer: \boxed{80}.


Question: There are 20 cars lined up at a race. Each of the cars have 2 passengers and a driver, then when the cars go past the race’s halfway point, each car gains another passenger. The cars then continue racing, and the race finishes once every single car has passed the finish line. People who get into the cars have to stay inside of them until the race is finished. How many people are in the cars by the end of the race?

At the start of the race, there are 20 cars with 2 passengers each and a driver, resulting in a total of 20 * (2 + 1) = <<20*(2+1)=60>>60 people.
When each car gains another passenger at the halfway point, the number of people in each car becomes 2 + 1 + 1 = 4.
Therefore, by the end of the race, there are 20 cars with 4 passengers each, resulting in a total of 20 * 4 = <<20*4=80>>80 people in the cars. Answer: \boxed{80}.


Question: There are 20 cars lined up at a race. Each of the cars have 2 passengers and a driver, then when the cars go past the race’s halfway point, each car gains another passenger. The cars then continue racing, and the race finishes once every single car has passed the finish line. People who get into the cars have to stay inside of them until the race is finished. How many people are in the cars by the end of the race?

At the start of the race, there are 20 cars x 3 people = <<20*3=60>>60 people in the cars.
At the halfway point, each car gains 1 passenger, so now there are 20 cars x 4 people = <<20*4=80>>80 people in the cars.
Therefore, by the end of the race, there are a total of 80 people in the cars. Answer: \boxed{80}.


Question: There are 20 cars lined up at a race. Each of the cars have 2 passengers and a driver, then when the cars go past the race’s halfway point, each car gains another passenger. The cars then continue racing, and the race finishes once every single car has passed the finish line. People who get into the cars have to stay inside of them until the race is finished. How many people are in the cars by the end of the race?

Initially, there are 20 cars * (2 passengers per car + 1 driver per car) = <<20*(2+1)=60>>60 people in the cars.
After passing the halfway point, each car gains another passenger, so there are now 20 cars * (2 passengers per car + 1 driver per car + 1 additional passenger per car) = <<20*(2+1+1)=80>>80 people in the cars.
Thus, by the end of the race, there are 80 people in the cars. Answer: \boxed{80}.


Question: Nate got lost looking for his car in the airport parking lot. He had to walk through every row in Section G and Section H to find it. Section G has 15 rows that each hold 10 cars. Section H has 20 rows that each hold 9 cars. If Nate can walk past 11 cars per minute, how many minutes did he spend searching the parking lot?

First find the total number of cars in section G: 15 rows * 10 cars/row = <<15*10=150>>150 cars
Then find the total number of cars in section H: 20 rows * 9 cars/row = <<20*9=180>>180 cars
Then add the number of cars in section G to the number of cars in section H to find the total number of cars: 150 cars + 180 cars = <<150+180=330>>330 cars
Then divide the number of cars Nate can walk by the number of cars he finds per minute to find how long he spends searching: 330 cars / 11 cars/minute = <<330/11=30>>30 minutes. Answer: \boxed{30}.


Question: There are 20 cars lined up at a race. Each of the cars have 2 passengers and a driver, then when the cars go past the race’s halfway point, each car gains another passenger. The cars then continue racing, and the race finishes once every single car has passed the finish line. People who get into the cars have to stay inside of them until the race is finished. How many people are in the cars by the end of the race?
text:
At the start of the race, there are 20 cars with 2 passengers each and a driver, resulting in a total of 20 * (2 + 1) = <<20*(2+1)=60>>60 people.
When each car gains another passenger at the halfway point, the number of people in each car becomes 2 + 1 + 1 = 4.
Therefore, by the end of the race, there are 20 cars with 4 passengers each, resulting in a total of 20 * 4 = <<20*4=80>>80 people in the cars. Answer: \boxed{80}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: You have 32$ to spend on groceries.  You buy a loaf of bread for 3$, a candy bar for 2$, and 1/3 of whats left on a Turkey.  How much money do you have left?

After purchasing the loaf of bread and candy bar, you have spent 3 + 2 = <<3+2=5>>5$.
You have 32 - 5 = <<32-5=27>>27$ left.
You spend 1/3 of the remaining money on a Turkey, so you spend 27 / 3 = <<27/3=9>>9$ on the Turkey.
Therefore, you have 27 - 9 = <<27-9=18>>18$ left. Answer: \boxed{18}.


Question: You have 32$ to spend on groceries.  You buy a loaf of bread for 3$, a candy bar for 2$, and 1/3 of whats left on a Turkey.  How much money do you have left?

You spend 3$ on bread and 2$ on a candy bar, which totals to 3+2 = <<3+2=5>>5 dollars.
After buying the bread and candy bar, you have 32-5 = <<32-5=27>>27 dollars left.
You then spend 1/3 of the remaining money on a turkey, which is 1/3*27 = <<1/3*27=9>>9 dollars.
After buying the turkey, you have 27-9 = <<27-9=18>>18 dollars left. Answer: \boxed{18}.


Question: You have 32$ to spend on groceries.  You buy a loaf of bread for 3$, a candy bar for 2$, and 1/3 of whats left on a Turkey.  How much money do you have left?

After buying the loaf of bread for $3, you have $32 - $3 = $<<32-3=29>>29 remaining to spend.
After buying the candy bar for $2, you have $29 - $2 = $<<29-2=27>>27 remaining to spend.
You spend 1/3 of what's left on a turkey, which is 1/3 * $27 = $<<1/3*27=9>>9.
Therefore, you have $27 - $9 = $<<27-9=18>>18 left. Answer: \boxed{18}.


Question: You have 32$ to spend on groceries.  You buy a loaf of bread for 3$, a candy bar for 2$, and 1/3 of whats left on a Turkey.  How much money do you have left?

You spent a total of 3$ on the loaf of bread and 2$ on the candy bar, which is a total of 3+2 = <<3+2=5>>5$.

Thus, you have 32-5= <<32-5=27>>27$ left.

Since you spent 1/3 of what was left on a Turkey, you spent (1/3)*27 = <<(1/3)*27=9>>9$ on the Turkey.

Thus, you have 27-9=<<27-9=18>>18$ left. Answer: \boxed{18}.


Question: You have 32$ to spend on groceries.  You buy a loaf of bread for 3$, a candy bar for 2$, and 1/3 of whats left on a Turkey.  How much money do you have left?

After buying a loaf of bread for $3 and a candy bar for $2, you have spent a total of $3 + $2 = $<<3+2=5>>5.
You initially had $32, so after spending $5, you have $32 - $5 = $<<32-5=27>>27 left.
1/3 of what you have left is $27 * (1/3) = $<<27*(1/3)=9>>9.
Therefore, you have $27 - $9 = $<<27-9=18>>18 left. Answer: \boxed{18}.


Question: You have 32$ to spend on groceries.  You buy a loaf of bread for 3$, a candy bar for 2$, and 1/3 of whats left on a Turkey.  How much money do you have left?
text:
You bought a loaf of bread for $3 and a candy bar for $2, which means you spent a total of $3 + $2 = $<<3+2=5>>5.
You had $32 to start with, so after spending $5, you have $32 - $5 = $<<32-5=27>>27 left.
Since you spent 1/3 of what you have left on a turkey, you spent (1/3)*$27 = $<<27*(1/3)=9>>9 on the turkey.
Thus, you have $27 - $9 = $<<27-9=18>>18 left. Answer: \boxed{18}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Ben spends 20% of his after-tax income on his car. If his car payment is $400 and he pays 1/3 of his gross income in taxes, how much does he make per month before taxes?

Let X be Ben's income before taxes
He pays 1/3*X in taxes
His after-tax income is X - 1/3*X = 2/3*X
His car payment is 20% * (2/3)X = $400
Thus 0.2 * (2/3)X = $400
(2/3)X = $400 / 0.2 = $2000
Thus X = ($2000)*(3/2) = $<<2000*(3/2)=3000>>3000. Answer: \boxed{3000}.


Question: Ben starts each day with $50, spends $15 every day and saves the rest. After a few days, his mom doubled his total savings and his dad gave him an additional $10. If he now has $500, How many days have elapsed?

Let's assume he has saved for x days.
The amount of money he saves each day is 50 - 15 = $<<50-15=35>>35.
In x days, he has saved 35 * x dollars.
His total savings now is 2 * 35 * x + 10 = 70x + 10 = $500.
70x = 490.
x = <<7=7>>7.
So, 7 days have elapsed. Answer: \boxed{7}.


Question: Ben's new car cost twice as much as his old car. He sold his old car for $1800 and used that to pay off some of the cost of his new car. He still owes another $2000 on his new car. How much did his old car cost, in dollars?

The new car cost 1800+2000=$<<1800+2000=3800>>3800.
The old car cost 3800/2=$<<3800/2=1900>>1900. Answer: \boxed{1900}.


Question: Ben's new car cost twice as much as his old car. He sold his old car for $1800 and used that to pay off some of the cost of his new car. He still owes another $2000 on his new car. How much did his old car cost, in dollars?

Ben's new car cost $1800 + $2000 = $<<1800+2000=3800>>3800
His old car cost $3800 / 2 = $<<3800/2=1900>>1900. Answer: \boxed{1900}.


Question: Ben's new car cost twice as much as his old car. He sold his old car for $1800 and used that to pay off some of the cost of his new car. He still owes another $2000 on his new car. How much did his old car cost, in dollars?

Ben's new car cost 1800+2000 = $<<1800+2000=3800>>3800
Ben's old car cost 3800/2 = $<<3800/2=1900>>1900. Answer: \boxed{1900}.


Question: Ben spends 20% of his after-tax income on his car. If his car payment is $400 and he pays 1/3 of his gross income in taxes, how much does he make per month before taxes?
text:
Let's assume Ben's income before taxes is X dollars.
He pays 1/3*X in taxes.
His after-tax income is X - 1/3*X = 2/3*X.
His car payment is 20% * (2/3)X = $400.
Thus, 0.2 * (2/3)X = $400.
Simplifying, we have (2/3)X = $400 / 0.2 = $2000.
To solve for X, we multiply both sides of the equation by (3/2):
X = ($2000)*(3/2) = $<<2000*(3/2)=3000>>3000.
Therefore, Ben makes $3000 per month before taxes. Answer: \boxed{3000}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Tom, an avid stamp collector, has 3,000 stamps in his collection. He is very sad because he lost his job last Friday. His brother, Mike, and best friend, Harry, try to cheer him up with more stamps. Harry’s gift to Tom is 10 more stamps than twice Mike’s gift. If Mike has given Tom 17 stamps, how many stamps does Tom’s collection now have?

Twice Mike’s gift is 17 * 2 = <<17*2=34>>34 stamps.
So, Harry has given Tom 34 + 10 = <<34+10=44>>44 stamps.
Earlier, Tom’s collection has 3,000 + 17 + 44 = <<3000+17+44=3061>>3061 stamps. Answer: \boxed{3061}.


Question: Tom, an avid stamp collector, has 3,000 stamps in his collection. He is very sad because he lost his job last Friday. His brother, Mike, and best friend, Harry, try to cheer him up with more stamps. Harry’s gift to Tom is 10 more stamps than twice Mike’s gift. If Mike has given Tom 17 stamps, how many stamps does Tom’s collection now have?

Twice Mike’s gift is 17 * 2 = <<17*2=34>>34 stamps.
Harry’s gift to Tom is 10 + 34 = <<10+34=44>>44 stamps.
In total, Tom receives 17 + 44 = <<17+44=61>>61 stamps.
Tom’s collection now has 3000 + 61 = <<3000+61=3061>>3061 stamps. Answer: \boxed{3061}.


Question: Tom, an avid stamp collector, has 3,000 stamps in his collection. He is very sad because he lost his job last Friday. His brother, Mike, and best friend, Harry, try to cheer him up with more stamps. Harry’s gift to Tom is 10 more stamps than twice Mike’s gift. So, Harry gave Tom 10 + 34 = <<10+34=44>>44 stamps.
Altogether, Tom's collection now has 3000 + 17 + 44 = <<3000+17+44=3061>>3061 stamps. Answer: \boxed{3061}.


Question: Tom, an avid stamp collector, has 3,000 stamps in his collection. He is very sad because he lost his job last Friday. His brother, Mike, and best friend, Harry, try to cheer him up with more stamps. Harry’s gift to Tom is 10 more stamps than twice Mike’s gift. Together, Mike and Harry have given Tom 44 stamps + 17 stamps = <<44+17=61>>61 stamps.
Thus, Tom's collection now has 3,000 stamps + 61 stamps = <<3000+61=3061>>3061 stamps. Answer: \boxed{3061}.


Question: Tom, an avid stamp collector, has 3,000 stamps in his collection. He is very sad because he lost his job last Friday. His brother, Mike, and best friend, Harry, try to cheer him up with more stamps. Harry’s gift to Tom is 10 more stamps than twice Mike’s gift. Harry’s gift to Tom is 10 more stamps than twice Mike’s gift, so Harry has given him 10 + 34 = <<10+34=44>>44 stamps.
Including those gifts, Tom’s stamp collection now has 44 + 17 + 3000 = <<44+17+3000=3061>>3061 stamps. Answer: \boxed{3061}.


Question: Tom, an avid stamp collector, has 3,000 stamps in his collection. He is very sad because he lost his job last Friday. His brother, Mike, and best friend, Harry, try to cheer him up with more stamps. Harry’s gift to Tom is 10 more stamps than twice Mike’s gift. So, Harry gave Tom 10 + 34 = <<10+34=44>>44 stamps.
In total, Tom received 17 + 44 = <<17+44=61>>61 stamps.
Therefore, Tom's collection now has 3000 + 61 = <<3000+61=3061>>3061 stamps. Answer: \boxed{3061}.

Question: Diana is twice as old as Grace is today. If Grace turned 3 a year ago, how old is Diana today?

If Grace turned 3 a year ago, she is now 4 years old.
Diana is twice as old as Grace is today, which means she is 2 * 4 = <<2*4=8>>8 years old. Answer: \boxed{8}.

text:
If Grace turned 3 a year ago, she is currently 3+1=<<3+1=4>>4 years old.
Since Diana is twice as old as Grace, Diana is currently 2 * 4 = <<2*4=8>>8 years old. Answer: \boxed{8}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: A parking garage of a mall is four stories tall. On the first level, there are 90 parking spaces. The second level has 8 more parking spaces than on the first level, and there are 12 more available parking spaces on the third level than on the second level. The fourth level has 9 fewer parking spaces than the third level. If 100 cars are already parked, how many cars can be accommodated by the parking garage?

On the second level, there are 90 + 8 = <<90+8=98>>98 parking spaces.
On the third level, there are 98 + 12 = <<98+12=110>>110 parking spaces.
On the fourth level, there are 110 - 9 = <<110-9=101>>101 parking spaces.
Altogether, there are 90 + 98 + 110 + 101 = <<90+98+110+101=399>>399 parking spaces.
Thus, the parking garage can accommodate 399 - 100 = <<399-100=299>>299 cars. Answer: \boxed{299}.


Question: A parking garage of a mall is four stories tall. On the first level, there are 90 parking spaces. The second level has 8 more parking spaces than on the first level, and there are 12 more available parking spaces on the third level than on the second level. The fourth level has 9 fewer parking spaces than the third level. If 100 cars are already parked, how many cars can be accommodated by the parking garage?

On the second level, there are 90 + 8 = <<90+8=98>>98 parking spaces.
On the third level, there are 98 + 12 = <<98+12=110>>110 parking spaces.
The fourth level has 110 - 9 = <<110-9=101>>101 parking spaces.
Therefore, there are a total of 90 + 98 + 110 + 101 = <<90+98+110+101=399>>399 parking spaces in the parking garage.
Hence, 399 - 100 = <<399-100=299>>299 parking spaces can be accommodated by the parking garage. Answer: \boxed{299}.


Question: A parking garage of a mall is four stories tall. On the first level, there are 90 parking spaces. The second level has 8 more parking spaces than on the first level, and there are 12 more available parking spaces on the third level than on the second level. The fourth level has 9 fewer parking spaces than the third level. If 100 cars are already parked, how many cars can be accommodated by the parking garage?

Since there are 90 parking spaces on the first level, the second level has 90 + 8 = <<90+8=98>>98 parking spaces.
The third level has 98 + 12 = <<98+12=110>>110 available parking spaces.
Since the fourth floor has 110 - 9 = <<110-9=101>>101 parking spaces.
Thus, the parking garage can accommodate 90 + 98 + 110 + 101 = <<90+98+110+101=399>>399 cars
Therefore, 399 - 100 = <<399-100=299>>299 cars can still be accommodated by the parking garage. Answer: \boxed{299}.


Question: Jason is planning a parking garage that will have 12 floors. Every 3rd floor has a gate where drivers have to show ID, which takes two minutes. To get from one floor to the next, drivers have to drive 800 feet at 10 feet/second. How long, in seconds, does it take to get to the bottom of the garage from the top?

The total time spent at the gates is 2 minutes/gate * 4 gates = <<2*4=8>>8 minutes
The total distance traveled between floors is 12 floors * 800 feet/floor = <<12*800=9600>>9600 feet
The total time traveling between floors is 9600 feet * 1 second/10 feet = <<9600/10=960>>960 seconds
The total time for the whole trip is 8 minutes * 60 seconds/minute + 960 seconds = 480 seconds + 960 seconds = <<8*60+960=1440>>1440 seconds. Answer: \boxed{1440}.


Question: In a town, there is a multi-story parking lot, which has room for 425 cars. The parking lot has 5 levels, each of the same size. How many more cars can one level fit if there are already 23 parked cars on that level?

Each level of the parking lot has a capacity of 425 cars / 5 levels = <<425/5=85>>85 cars.
So one level can fit 85 cars - 23 cars = <<85-23=62>>62 more cars. Answer: \boxed{62}.


Question: A parking garage of a mall is four stories tall. On the first level, there are 90 parking spaces. The second level has 8 more parking spaces than on the first level, and there are 12 more available parking spaces on the third level than on the second level. The fourth level has 9 fewer parking spaces than the third level. If 100 cars are already parked, how many cars can be accommodated by the parking garage?
text:
On the second level, there are 90 + 8 = 98 parking spaces.
On the third level, there are 98 + 12 = 110 parking spaces.
On the fourth level, there are 110 - 9 = 101 parking spaces.
Altogether, there are 90 + 98 + 110 + 101 = 399 parking spaces.
Thus, the parking garage can accommodate 399 - 100 = 299 cars. Answer: \boxed{299}.
